The TCP/IP reference model was developed by the Department of Defense (DoD) in the 1970s. However, the fundamental communication protocols at the heart of the Internet, the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and the Internet Protocol (IP), were invented by Robert Elliot Kahn and Vint Cerf. In 1974, Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn published the specifications for Transmission Control Protocol (TCP), an internetworking protocol for sharing resources using packet-switching among the nodes. Additionally, IP was the connectionless datagram service in the original Transmission Control Program introduced by Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn in 1974, which was complemented by a connection-oriented service that became the basis for the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP).

John Romkey and Donald W. Gillies developed the first in the industry TCP/IP stack for IBM PC in 1983, founding FTP Software, a commercial TCP/IP stack provider in 1986. This provides additional context about the development of the TCP/IP stack.

The TCP/IP reference model was developed by the Department of Defense (DoD), with the fundamental communication protocols TCP and IP being invented by Robert Elliot Kahn and Vint Cerf. Additionally, John Romkey and Donald W. Gillies developed the first in the industry TCP/IP stack for IBM PC in 1983, providing further advancements in the development of the TCP/IP model.
